conversation.content: They told me you were captured near the eastern checkpoint, but, um, your accent—that's not from across the border, is it? That's from Kravina village.
[coldly] Kravina doesn't exist anymore, Colonel. You should know that better than anyone since your people, ahh, redrew the maps six months ago and renamed everything.

[leaning forward] My grandmother was born in Kravina, used to make this specific bread with caraway seeds that I can still smell sometimes, and now you're sitting here wearing their uniform? [bitter laugh]
Your grandmother would probably understand why some of us chose differently when the annexation happened, when we had to pick between, um, keeping our homes or keeping our principles.
[quietly] You know what they're calling people like you back home? Traitors who sold their birthright for foreign promises that'll never materialize once this war ends.
[steady] And what do they call people like you who arrest their own cousins and neighbors for refusing to sign loyalty oaths to a flag that wasn't theirs six months ago? Patriots?
I'm trying to, erhm, understand how someone from our soil, our blood, ends up pointing rifles at us. Help me understand that logic.

[exhausted] Logic? You want logic? Your nation swallowed my home, demanded we forget our language, our customs, and when we resisted, you called us insurgents. [sighs heavily] Where's the logic in that?
[frustrated growl] We offered citizenship, protection, prosperity—everything your previous government couldn't provide, and this is how you repay that generosity? By joining them?
Generosity. [hollow laugh] That's what you're calling it when soldiers kicked down doors at three in the morning looking for anyone who wouldn't hang your flag?
Those were necessary security measures during the transition period, and, look, I'm not proud of everything that happened, but stability required certain, um, certain unfortunate actions.
[voice rising] Unfortunate actions? My brother disappeared during your 'transition period,' and his wife still doesn't know if he's in some detention camp or just, just gone.
[defensive] Every revolution, every unification has casualties—people who can't adapt to progress, who cling to old divisions that only weaken us all. Your brother chose his side.
He chose to keep speaking our dialect at the market, that's all. [voice breaking] That was his revolutionary act that threatened your glorious unified state so much.
[softer] Listen, I can, maybe I can check the detention records, see if he's—but you have to give me something first. The supply routes your unit uses.
[bitterly] Ahhh, there it is. The nationalist's bargain—betray everyone else I care about for a chance to maybe learn about one. Some things don't change.
This is bigger than your village grudges, don't you see that? We're building something that'll last generations, something our grandchildren will thank us for. [pleading slightly]
[quietly defiant] My grandchildren, if I ever have any, will know I stood against an occupation, not for some grand vision built on, um, on conquered villages and disappeared brothers.

[standing abruptly] You have until morning to reconsider. After that, well, enemy combatants who refuse cooperation don't usually get second chances in this facility. [pause] Think about your brother.
[resigned whisper] I am.

scenario: A captured enemy soldier is interrogated by a nationalist military officer who discovers the prisoner is actually from his grandmother's annexed village.
